newsitem.title: USA: Israeli minister no match for chess super-computer.
newsitem.headline: Israeli minister no match for chess super-computer.

text.p: Natan Sharansky, Israel's minister of industry and trade, on Monday played -- and lost -- against the technology behind the world's reigning chess champion, IBM's Deep Blue computer.

Sharansky faced off against Deep Blue Junior, a scaled-down version of the super-computer that defeated reigning world champion Garry Kasparov in May, during a ministerial visit to IBM's research headquarters 50 miles (80 km) north of New York City.
The Minister vs. Machine match ended after less than two hours, with Deep Blue Jr. winning the three games played.

Sharansky, leader of the Yisrael ba-Aliya (Israel of Immigration) party, is an avid chess player who honed his skills during nine years behind bars as a Jewish dissident in the former Soviet Union. He was involved in programming some of the first chess-playing computers 25 years ago, he said.
He told Reuters he was extremely impressed with the "fantastic achievements" of Deep Blue Jr., which can examine 20 million possible moves per second and has never been beaten by a grandmaster.
"When playing with this computer, you learn you are powerless, you learn there is no way to provoke it," Sharansky said. "It's a very interesting feeling."

Deep Blue Senior, an IBM RS/6000 parallel processor with specialised chess microchips that can examine hundreds of millions of possible moves per second, made history on May 11 when it defeated Kasparov in a six-game match. It became the first chess-playing machine to win a match in a traditional format, in which games can last up to seven hours.
Kasparov, a grandmaster known for his brilliant, quick style of play, was stunned by his defeat and has called for a rematch by year's end.
Sharansky said he played against Kasparov last December when the grandmaster visited Israel. As one of 25 competitors simultaneously playing against him, Sharansky won his match.
